strengths.concept_label: Basic Risk: Maximum loss on a long options position
strengths.description: Understands that buying a call option caps the maximum loss to the premium paid, correctly distinguishing the asymmetric risk profile of long options from short positions or direct stock ownership where losses can be far larger.

strengths.concept_label: Covered Calls: Income generation from existing holdings
strengths.description: Knows to sell exactly 2 contracts to match a 200-share holding and targets the $190 strike aligned with the desired exit price — demonstrates practical covered call sizing, contract-to-share ratio awareness, and income-vs-exit goal alignment.

strengths.concept_label: Time Decay (Theta): How options lose value over time
strengths.description: Correctly attributes the erosion of option value near expiration to Theta (time decay) rather than Delta or volatility changes — shows awareness that time itself is a built-in cost when holding long options, critical for trade timing decisions.

strengths.concept_label: Delta: Option price sensitivity to underlying movement
strengths.description: Understands Delta as the rate of change of an option's price per $1 move in the underlying stock — a foundational Greek concept essential for position sizing, hedging ratios, and understanding directional exposure.

strengths.concept_label: Cash-Secured Puts: Strategic entry at target price with premium income
strengths.description: Recognises that selling cash-secured puts is the optimal strategy to acquire a stock at a desired lower price while collecting premium income in the meantime — avoids the purely passive 'wait and watch' approach and understands the obligation being taken on.

Correctly understands that option prices rise before earnings announcements due to implied volatility expansion driven by uncertainty — critical knowledge for timing option entries and exits around catalyst events.

strengths.concept_label: Multi-Leg Strategies: Iron condor mechanics and profit conditions
strengths.description: Correctly identifies that an iron condor profits when the underlying stays range-bound between the two short strikes — demonstrates understanding of 4-leg strategy construction, defined-risk mechanics, and the neutrality bias of the position.

weaknesses.concept_label: Portfolio Protection: Using puts to hedge downside risk
weaknesses.description: Chose 'Buy more tech stocks when they drop' instead of buying protective puts.
weaknesses.misconception: Defaults to a buy-the-dip reflex under market stress rather than recognising that protective puts allow staying invested in the portfolio while capping downside risk. Conflates bullish conviction with risk management — misses that options can act as portfolio insurance without requiring liquidation.

weaknesses.concept_label: Assignment Mechanics: What happens when ITM options expire
weaknesses.description: Chose 'Keep the stock and the $3' instead of recognising that ITM calls at expiry result in share assignment.
weaknesses.misconception: Does not account for the near-certain assignment when a covered call expires in-the-money. Treats the covered call as if it simply expires worthlessly regardless of where the stock trades. Misses the core obligation: when the short call is ITM at expiry, the seller is expected to deliver shares at the strike price — keeping both the stock and premium is not an option.

weaknesses.concept_label: Expiration Management: Actively managing ITM positions near expiry
weaknesses.description: Chose 'Let them all expire automatically' instead of managing each position based on assignment risk and portfolio impact.
weaknesses.misconception: Treats multiple ITM options expiring simultaneously as passive, self-resolving events. Underestimates the compounding assignment risk, potential capital requirement, and portfolio-level disruption of allowing 5 concurrent ITM positions to expire without active review or decision-making on each.

weaknesses.concept_label: Gamma: Accelerating delta sensitivity near expiry
weaknesses.description: Chose 'You're protected against volatility' — which is the opposite of what high Gamma implies.
weaknesses.misconception: Inverts the actual meaning of high Gamma exposure. High Gamma means that Delta is rapidly changing and even small moves in the underlying can cause large, accelerating swings in option value — making the portfolio more sensitive and unstable, not protected. Conflates a risk amplifier with a risk mitigant.

weaknesses.concept_label: Volatility Crush: Post-earnings IV collapse and its impact on options
weaknesses.description: Chose 'Time decay acceleration' to explain a 30% overnight options loss when the stock only dropped 5%.
weaknesses.misconception: Misattributes a sharp post-earnings options loss to Theta (time decay) when the magnitude and speed of the loss — overnight, on a minor stock move — is a classic signature of implied volatility crush. Misses that IV collapses sharply once the earnings uncertainty resolves, deflating option premiums regardless of whether the stock moves in the anticipated direction.

available_actions: Covered calls on your existing stocks
Real-time P&L with your actual tickers
Position sizes up to 10% of portfolio
